conclusion: To determine the work done by the gas when it changes from state B to state C.
The process from state B to state C involves a constant pressure change (isobaric process), as both states have the same pressure \( p = 0.6p_0 \).
For an isobaric process, the work done \( W \) by the gas can be calculated using the formula: \( W = P \Delta V \).
Volume at state B, \( V_B = V_0 \); Volume at state C, \( V_C = 0.5V_0 \).
The change in volume \( \Delta V \) is: \( \Delta V = V_C - V_B = 0.5V_0 - V_0 = -0.5V_0 \).
Substitute values into the work formula: Given pressure \( P = 0.6p_0 \) and change in volume \( \Delta V = -0.5V_0 \), the work done \( W = (0.6p_0) \times (-0.5V_0) = -0.3p_0 V_0 \).
The work done by the gas when it changes from state B to state C is \( \boxed{-0.3p_0 V_0} \).
